turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: So how do you feel about giving money to charity?

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: I generally disagree, I am only willing to give to charity after I have thoroughly researched the organization.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: In this instance though, the money you'd be given is freely available to you, and costs you nothing.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: I suppose that's true. But how can I give something that isn't mine?

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Well it is yours for the purpose of this conversation, and the money would go towards a good cause.  Save the Children is a recognized organization that has promoted children's  rights since 1919.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: In that case I would not donate my money.  Every charity that has ever existed said the money would go towards a good cause.  I know nothing about Save the Children other than what you've just told me.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Well the organization does have consultative ties to the United Nations Economic and Social Council.  They provide aid to children for education, health care, economic opportunities, along with emergency aid during natural disasters, war and other conflicts.  They've provided aid during the Russian famine in 1921, were among the first into liberated areas after World War 2 to work with refugee children and survivors of Nazi concentration camps, etc.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: I'd have to research several sources, and documentation for myself.  Although the face of any charity looks good, I don't trust any charity until I've seen proof.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Well they are highly rated, with Charity Navigator give them a score of 88.3 out of 100.  Would you be willing to give at least a small portion of the money you have?

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Nope, never heard of Charity Navigator, but it sounds like a good place to start.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Are you sure not even a small amount.  They instituted the Rewrite the Future global campaign in 2006 that focused on obtaining equal and quality education for children who are unable to attend school due to conflict or war. The campaign is focused in 28 states where armed conflict is particularly relevant including Afghanistan, Angola, Colombia, Ivory Coast, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Haiti, Indonesia, Liberia, Nepal, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sudan, Sri Lanka, and Uganda.  In 2008, they surpassed their goal by improving education standards for 10 million instead of 8.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: I'm sure, like I said, that sounds great, but anyone can say anything is true.  I need proof.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Well I can link their website right now for you to glance over:  URL

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: That looks like a great organization. But I have to be clear, I've studied the wrong doings of large institutions, and there is potential for the funds to line somebody's pockets, instead of helping more. For example, even good organizations pay companies to solicit for them, those companies keep 85-90% of all donations.  I'm not taking a chance.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: But they've won multiple awards from a list of non-profit grading organizations include Great Noprofits, GuideStar Platinum, and most importantly the Better Business Bureau that rates based on utilization of funds.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: That's cool, never heard of Great Noprofits or GuideStar Platinum, so those awards mean nothing to me right now. I'm familiar with the BBB but not how they rate charities.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Well, the BBB rates and accredits charities based on 20 criteria.  These include board oversight, size, conflicts of interest, program expenses, auditing reports, test for accurate expense reporting, website disclosures, include any true complaints against the charity, effectiveness policy, budget plan, etc.  They passed all 20 criteria.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Well that's good to know.  But it still isn't something I have researched myself.  No way am I willing to give any amount of money away to an organization I've only heard about just a few minutes ago.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: If you're worried about how the money is spent, the BBB reported Save the Children committed 122 million to education, 205 million to emergencies, 144 million to health/nutrition, 42 million to HIV/AIDS, etc.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Great, I still need to see it for myself.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Well all I could do was provide that information, and let you make up your own mind.  Good luck to you.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Thanks, good luck to you too!
